<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Good Saturday morning.</strong> Here's a hypothetical question we not-so-hypothetically faced recently: You have a 75% stale bagel that could be edible if heated up. The problem is, the only way you could heat it up is in a microwave.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Do you a) use the microwave and try to sneak in a couple bites before the bagel's really donezo or b) take the L and keep your honor intact? Thank you in advance for your wise counsel.</p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
FINANCE
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2019/10/04/robot-invasion-finance-begun?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Can a Robot Pull Off Deal Sleds?
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Can a Robot Pull Off Deal Sleds?" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiIxNTcwMjIwMTYyLmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im1vcm5pbmdicmV3LW9zbG8iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Francis Scialabba</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">First, the robot army conquered the relatively simple task of buying and selling securities. Now, they’re coming for much more sophisticated jobs in finance, like solving complex macroeconomic puzzles. What'll it be next...D3 lacrosse?</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The Economist <a href="https://www.economist.com/leaders/2019/10/03/the-rise-of-the-financial-machines?utm_source=newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=newsletter_axiosam&stream=top&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">this week laid out</a> just how quickly automation is taking over finance. Funds run by computers that follow human-set rules account for...</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>35% of the U.S. stock market</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>60% of institutional equity assets</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>60% of trading activity</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Last month, exchange-traded funds (ETFs) and mutual funds automatically tracking stock and bond indices hit $4.3 trillion invested in American equities, surpassing the sum run by humans for the first time.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Some risks</strong>, per The Economist:</p>
<ol>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Financial stability. Ever heard of a </span><span><a href="https://www.investopedia.com/terms/f/flash-crash.asp?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">flash crash</a></span><span>?</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Wealth concentration. Automation performs better with enormous computing power, and enormous computing power costs enormous money.</span></li>
</ol>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">The big picture</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Nobody’s going to get hurt when Alexa messes up the weather forecast. But automation in finance brings much higher stakes. It can impact c-suite decisions, redistribute wealth, and torpedo the economy. And if human bankers don’t understand how machine learning is...learning, it’s hard to stop SELL SELL SELL orders once they start.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The bad news: </strong>“<a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-10-02/robots-to-cut-200-000-u-s-bank-jobs-in-next-decade-study-says?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Technological efficiencies</a>” will lead to about <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/emerging-tech/stories/2019/10/04/wells-fargo-robots-will-displace-200000-banking-jobs-next-decade?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">200,000 job cuts</a> in the U.S. banking industry over the next decade, Wells Fargo said this week. And PwC <a href="https://www.ft.com/content/c4bf787a-d4a0-11e9-a0bd-ab8ec6435630?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">found last year</a> that about 30% of finance and insurance jobs in developed economies will be at risk of automation by 2029.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The good news: </strong>It’s not the grades you make, it’s the skills you fake. Finance industry job listings requiring skills in artificial intelligence, machine learning, and data science increased almost 60% over the last year.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line: </strong>U.S. finance firms are spending more than any other industry on tech—a grand total of $150 billion/year.</p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
JOBS
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2019/10/04/september-jobs-report-numbers?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Significant Figures From the September Jobs Report
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">136,000</strong>—Jobs <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/us-adds-modest-136000-jobs-lowering-unemployment-to-35percent/2019/10/04/32be1788-e6c0-11e9-b0a6-3d03721b85ef_story.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">added</a> <span>to the U.S. economy</span> last month, ~10,000 fewer than economists expected. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">2.9%</strong>—Increase in hourly pay from a year earlier. That’s <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/u-s-september-nonfarm-payrolls-grew-steadily-11570192288?mod=article_inline&mod=hp_lead_pos1&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">lower than expected</a> but still higher than the inflation rate.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">11,400</strong>—Jobs <em>lost </em>in the retail sector in September. Retail <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2019/10/04/retailshed-11400-jobs-last-month.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">has shed</a> 197,000 jobs since <span>peaking</span> in Jan. 2017. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">3.5%</strong>—U.S. unemployment rate. It’s the lowest since December 1969 and below the 3.7% rate recorded in August. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">999999999999999</strong>—Sorry dozed off for a sec.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">108</strong>—Consecutive months of <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/10/04/business/economy/jobs-report.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">job growth</a> in the U.S. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">161,000</strong>—Average number of jobs created monthly so far in 2019. Last year, 223,000 jobs were created each month on average. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">?</strong>—Rate cuts announced by the Fed at its meeting in a few weeks. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Arguments for:</strong></span><span> this week’s scary-bad U.S. manufacturing data and economic warning signs from around the world.</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Arguments against: </strong></span><span>nine straight years of job growth and a historically strong labor market.</span>
</li>
</ul>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
MEDIA
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2019/10/04/wsj-report-disney-banned-netflix-ads-across-entertainment-tv-networks?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Cost of Streaming Wars Ads Up
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Cost of Streaming Wars Ads Up" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiIxNTcwMjEzMTU3LmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im1vcm5pbmdicmV3LW9zbG8iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Francis Scialabba</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">This week’s news cycle proves beyond a reasonable doubt that the so-called streaming wars are reaching a fever pitch. Today’s evidence: Disney (+1.65%) is banning Netflix (+1.73%) ads across all of its TV networks besides ESPN, <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/disney-bans-netflix-ads-as-streamings-marketing-wars-intensify-11570199291?mod=hp_lead_pos6&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">per the WSJ</a>.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The means:</strong> Disney, AT&T, and Comcast will spend hundreds of millions on ads over the next year to recruit customers to their forthcoming direct-to-consumer <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2019/10/04/disney-to-ban-netflix-ads-from-all-of-its-tv-services-except-espn-wsj.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">streaming services</a>. Netflix dished out $1.8 billion on advertising last year, $99.2 million of which went to U.S. television ads.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The motive: </strong>Disney found common ground with every streaming rival...except Netflix. Netflix doesn’t run ads—that’s great for us, but it means Disney <a href="https://www.theverge.com/2019/10/4/20898701/disney-netflix-ads-networks-abc-streaming-wars-amazon-fire-tv-apple?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">can’t promote</a> on Netflix’s platform like Netflix can on Disney’s.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Another exception...</strong></span><span>Amazon, which (as of Thursday) was </span><span><a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/amazon-disney-fight-over-ad-revenue-from-apps-on-fire-tv-11570117659?mod=article_inline&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">battling Disney</a></span><span> over terms for Disney apps on Amazon’s Fire TV, the second-largest distributor of streaming apps.</span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The opportunity: </strong>TV networks have generally banned ads from rival networks; we don’t remember seeing a <em>Gossip Girl</em> spot during <em>Glee</em>. But the decision to bar streamers marks a significant development in the battle for cord-cutting eyeballs.</p>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
ENERGY
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2019/10/04/bps-chief-stepping?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
BP Chief’s Gonna Be Free, Chief
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="BP Chief’s Gonna Be Free, Chief" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiIxNTcwMjE0Nzk3LmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im1vcm5pbmdicmV3LW9zbG8iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Dan Kitwood/Getty Images News/Getty Images</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">BP (+1.62%) CEO Bob Dudley said yesterday <a href="https://www.cnn.com/2019/10/04/business/bob-dudley-bp-ceo-retires/index.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">he’ll step down</a> from the energy leader <span>in February</span>. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The backstory: </strong>When Dudley took over in 2010, he basically bought a house that had burned to the ground. Just six months earlier, the Deepwater Horizon accident led to one of the worst oil spills in history.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>An explosion on a BP rig killed 11 workers, and nearly 5 million barrels of oil </span><span><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2010/08/03/us/03spill.html?_r=1&fta=y&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">leaked into</a></span><span> the Gulf of Mexico. </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">It’s always darkest just before it stays dark:</strong> A few years later, Dudley steered BP through 2014’s oil price collapse. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Since then, Dudley’s rebuilt BP into a sturdy three-bedroom, mostly by investing in U.S. shale. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>BP shares have rebounded 60% since their bottom post-disaster, </span><span><span>but are still hovering 24% below pre-Deepwater Horizon levels</span></span><span>. </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">But BP isn’t out of the woods. </strong>Oil companies are facing <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/bp-chief-dudley-to-step-down-having-steered-oil-giant-through-gulf-disaster-11570171546?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">unprecedented pressure</a> to reduce their carbon <span>emissions</span>. That’s tough...because almost all their profit comes from carbon-generated energy.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Looking ahead...</strong>Dudley’s successor, Bernard Looney, will have fun tackling that dilemma.</p>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
SPORTS
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="#" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
So That's a Good Spikeball Point

Now, they’re coming for much more sophisticated jobs in finance, like solving complex macroeconomic puzzles. What'll it be next...D3 lacrosse?\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe Economist \u003ca href=\"https://www.economist.com/leaders/2019/10/03/the-rise-of-the-financial-machines?utm_source=newsletter\u0026utm_medium=email\u0026utm_campaign=newsletter_axiosam\u0026stream=top\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ethis week laid out\u003c/a\u003e just how quickly automation is taking over finance. Funds run by computers that follow human-set rules account for...\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003e35% of the U.S. stock market\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003e60% of institutional equity assets\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003e60% of trading activity\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eLast month, exchange-traded funds (ETFs) and mutual funds automatically tracking stock and bond indices hit $4.3 trillion invested in American equities, surpassing the sum run by humans for the first time.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eSome risks\u003c/strong\u003e, per The Economist:\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003col\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eFinancial stability. Ever heard of a \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.investopedia.com/terms/f/flash-crash.asp?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eflash crash\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e?\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eWealth concentration. Automation performs better with enormous computing power, and enormous computing power costs enormous money.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ol\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eThe big picture\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eNobody’s going to get hurt when Alexa messes up the weather forecast. But automation in finance brings much higher stakes. It can impact c-suite decisions, redistribute wealth, and torpedo the economy. And if human bankers don’t understand how machine learning is...learning, it’s hard to stop SELL SELL SELL orders once they start.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe bad news: \u003c/strong\u003e“\u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-10-02/robots-to-cut-200-000-u-s-bank-jobs-in-next-decade-study-says?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eTechnological efficiencies\u003c/a\u003e” will lead to about \u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/emerging-tech/stories/2019/10/04/wells-fargo-robots-will-displace-200000-banking-jobs-next-decade?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e200,000 job cuts\u003c/a\u003e in the U.S. banking industry over the next decade, Wells Fargo said this week. And PwC \u003ca href=\"https://www.ft.com/content/c4bf787a-d4a0-11e9-a0bd-ab8ec6435630?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003efound last year\u003c/a\u003e that about 30% of finance and insurance jobs in developed economies will be at risk of automation by 2029.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe good news: \u003c/strong\u003eIt’s not the grades you make, it’s the skills you fake. Finance industry job listings requiring skills in artificial intelligence, machine learning, and data science increased almost 60% over the last year.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/us-adds-modest-136000-jobs-lowering-unemployment-to-35percent/2019/10/04/32be1788-e6c0-11e9-b0a6-3d03721b85ef_story.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eadded\u003c/a\u003e \u003cspan\u003eto the U.S. economy\u003c/span\u003e last month, ~10,000 fewer than economists expected. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e2.9%\u003c/strong\u003e—Increase in hourly pay from a year earlier. That’s \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/u-s-september-nonfarm-payrolls-grew-steadily-11570192288?mod=article_inline\u0026mod=hp_lead_pos1\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003elower than expected\u003c/a\u003e but still higher than the inflation rate.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e11,400\u003c/strong\u003e—Jobs \u003cem\u003elost \u003c/em\u003ein the retail sector in September. Retail \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2019/10/04/retailshed-11400-jobs-last-month.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ehas shed\u003c/a\u003e 197,000 jobs since \u003cspan\u003epeaking\u003c/span\u003e in Jan. 2017. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e3.5%\u003c/strong\u003e—U.S. unemployment rate. It’s the lowest since December 1969 and below the 3.7% rate recorded in August. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e999999999999999\u003c/strong\u003e—Sorry dozed off for a sec.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e108\u003c/strong\u003e—Consecutive months of \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2019/10/04/business/economy/jobs-report.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ejob growth\u003c/a\u003e in the U.S. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e161,000\u003c/strong\u003e—Average number of jobs created monthly so far in 2019. Last year, 223,000 jobs were created each month on average. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e?\u003c/strong\u003e—Rate cuts announced by the Fed at its meeting in a few weeks. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eArguments for:\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e this week’s scary-bad U.S. manufacturing data and economic warning signs from around the world.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003enine straight years of job growth and a historically strong labor market.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThis week’s news cycle proves beyond a reasonable doubt that the so-called streaming wars are reaching a fever pitch. Today’s evidence: Disney (+1.65%) is banning Netflix (+1.73%) ads across all of its TV networks besides ESPN, \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/disney-bans-netflix-ads-as-streamings-marketing-wars-intensify-11570199291?mod=hp_lead_pos6\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eper the WSJ\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe means:\u003c/strong\u003e Disney, AT\u0026T, and Comcast will spend hundreds of millions on ads over the next year to recruit customers to their forthcoming direct-to-consumer \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2019/10/04/disney-to-ban-netflix-ads-from-all-of-its-tv-services-except-espn-wsj.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003estreaming services\u003c/a\u003e. Netflix dished out $1.8 billion on advertising last year, $99.2 million of which went to U.S. television ads.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe motive: \u003c/strong\u003eDisney found common ground with every streaming rival...except Netflix. Netflix doesn’t run ads—that’s great for us, but it means Disney \u003ca href=\"https://www.theverge.com/2019/10/4/20898701/disney-netflix-ads-networks-abc-streaming-wars-amazon-fire-tv-apple?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ecan’t promote\u003c/a\u003e on Netflix’s platform like Netflix can on Disney’s.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eAnother exception...\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eAmazon, which (as of Thursday) was \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/amazon-disney-fight-over-ad-revenue-from-apps-on-fire-tv-11570117659?mod=article_inline\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ebattling Disney\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e over terms for Disney apps on Amazon’s Fire TV, the second-largest distributor of streaming apps.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe opportunity: \u003c/strong\u003eTV networks have generally banned ads from rival networks; we don’t remember seeing a \u003cem\u003eGossip Girl\u003c/em\u003e spot during \u003cem\u003eGlee\u003c/em\u003e. href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2010/08/03/us/03spill.html?_r=1\u0026fta=y\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eleaked into\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e the Gulf of Mexico. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eIt’s always darkest just before it stays dark:\u003c/strong\u003e A few years later, Dudley steered BP through 2014’s oil price collapse. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eSince then, Dudley’s rebuilt BP into a sturdy three-bedroom, mostly by investing in U.S. shale. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eBP shares have rebounded 60% since their bottom post-disaster, \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cspan\u003ebut are still hovering 24% below pre-Deepwater Horizon levels\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBut BP isn’t out of the woods. \u003c/strong\u003eOil companies are facing \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/bp-chief-dudley-to-step-down-having-steered-oil-giant-through-gulf-disaster-11570171546?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eunprecedented pressure\u003c/a\u003e to reduce their carbon \u003cspan\u003eemissions\u003c/span\u003e. That’s tough...because almost all their profit comes from carbon-generated energy.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong
